Bug ID / Report Number: A unique tracking number or identifier for the defect.
Summary / Abstract: A one-line, high-level description of the problem — clear and concise.
Tester Name: Who found and reported the bug.
Date Reported: When the bug was discovered or entered into the system.
Product / Module: The product name and the specific module, component, or feature affected.
Version / Build Number: Exact software version tested (e.g., v1.2 Build 46")."
Environment: Hardware, OS, browser, or configuration used during testing (helps reproduce).
Severity Level: How serious the bug is (e.g., 1 = Critical, 2 = Major, 3 = Minor, 4 = Trivial).
Priority: The order in which the bug should be fixed (often set by developers or QA leads).
Steps to Reproduce: Detailed, step-by-step instructions to make the bug happen again.
Expected Result: What should have happened according to requirements or user expectations.
Actual Result: What actually occurred when executing the steps.
Reproducibility / Frequency: Whether the bug happens always, sometimes, or rarely.
Attachments / Evidence: Screenshots, logs, test data, or crash dumps supporting the report.
Status: Current state — e.g., New, Open, In Progress, Fixed, Deferred, Closed.
Assigned To / Owner: Developer or team responsible for fixing it.
Bug Cost: How much time the bug costs both the tester and developer?
Notes / Comments: Any additional information, retest results, or observations.

Summary / Abstract: Subordinates disappear from display when manager is fired
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Initialize president. 2. HIRE President1 VP1. 3. HIRE VP1 Super1. 4. HIRE Super1 Worker1. 5. FIRE President1 VP1. 6. DISPLAY
Expected Result: Display should show: VACANCY: Vice President with Super1 and Worker1 beneath it in hierarchy
Actual Result: Subordinates (Super1, Worker1) completely disappear from display. Only shows President and VACANCY
Bug Cost: Critical - Violates SRS requirement 11. Data loss appearance
Notes / Comments: Related to _display_loop not recursing into Vacancy objects

Summary / Abstract: System accepts numeric names for president
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Start program. 2. Enter "123" as president name. 3. Program accepts it
Expected Result: System should reject numeric-only names with error message
Actual Result: System accepts "123" as valid president name
Bug Cost: High - Violates naming conventions in SRS
Notes / Comments: _valid_name() only checks for spaces and empty strings

Summary / Abstract: System accepts numeric names for employees
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Initialize president. 2. HIRE President1 999. 3. System accepts it
Expected Result: System should reject numeric-only names with error message
Actual Result: System accepts "999" as valid employee name
Bug Cost: High - Violates naming conventions
Notes / Comments: Same root cause as BUG-002

Summary / Abstract: System accepts special characters in employee names
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Initialize president. 2. HIRE President1 Test@123. 3. System accepts it
Expected Result: System should reject names with special characters like @ # $ %
Actual Result: System accepts special characters in names
Bug Cost: Security risk - could allow SQL injection or escape sequence attacks
Notes / Comments: Also accepts underscores and hyphens (BBT085-086)

Summary / Abstract: Names are case-sensitive allowing duplicate entries
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Initialize president. 2. HIRE President1 VP1. 3. HIRE President1 vp1. 4. Both succeed
Expected Result: System should reject "vp1" as duplicate of "VP1" (case-insensitive)
Actual Result: System treats "VP1" and "vp1" as different people
Bug Cost: Can lead to confusion with ""Bob"" and ""bob"" as different employees
Notes / Comments: Name uniqueness check needs case-insensitive comparison

Summary / Abstract: Names with leading/trailing spaces not properly rejected
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Initialize president. 2. HIRE President1 "  SpaceName  ". 3. May be accepted
Expected Result: System should strip or reject names with leading/trailing whitespace
Actual Result: Inconsistent handling of whitespace in names
Bug Cost: Low priority but should be sanitized
Notes / Comments: _valid_name() checks for spaces but not leading/trailing

Summary / Abstract: VP can promote Supervisor creating invalid VP under VP hierarchy
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Initialize president. 2. HIRE President1 VP1. 3. HIRE President1 VP2. 4. HIRE VP2 S1. 5. PROMOTE VP1 S1. 6. Creates VP under VP
Expected Result: System should reject - only President can have VPs as direct reports
Actual Result: Allows creation of VP (S1) reporting to another VP (VP1), breaking hierarchy rules
Bug Cost: Critical - Violates SRS hierarchy structure
Notes / Comments: promote_employee() doesn't validate receiving manager's level

Summary / Abstract: Repeated promotions can create unlimited VP levels
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Initialize president. 2. HIRE President1 VP1. 3. HIRE VP1 S1. 4. HIRE S1 W1. 5. PROMOTE VP1 W1. 6. PROMOTE VP1 W1 again
Expected Result: Second promotion should fail - already Supervisor
Actual Result: Can repeatedly promote creating nested VP structures (VP under VP under VP, etc.)
Bug Cost: Critical - Completely breaks organizational hierarchy
Notes / Comments: Related to BUG-007

Summary / Abstract: Empty name input doesn't reprompt properly
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Start program. 2. Press Enter (empty name). 3. Press Enter again. 4. Enter valid name
Expected Result: System should repeatedly prompt until valid name provided
Actual Result: Program may accept empty input or not handle multiple invalid attempts properly
Bug Cost: User experience issue
Notes / Comments: initialize_president() validation needs loop

Summary / Abstract: Invalid president name causes program to get stuck
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Start program. 2. Enter invalid name (empty). 3. Enter invalid name again. 4. Program doesn't properly reprompt
Expected Result: System should keep prompting for valid president name
Actual Result: Program may hang or not properly handle sequential invalid inputs
Bug Cost: Related to BUG-009
Notes / Comments: Input validation loop issue

Summary / Abstract: Subordinates lost after multiple cascading fires
Steps to Reproduce: 1. HIRE President1 VP1. 2. HIRE VP1 S1. 3. HIRE VP1 S2. 4. HIRE S1 W1. 5. HIRE S2 W2. 6. FIRE President1 VP1. 7. DISPLAY
Expected Result: Workers W1 and W2 should be visible under vacancy hierarchy
Actual Result: Workers completely disappear from display
Bug Cost: Critical - Same root cause as BUG-001
Notes / Comments: Multiple levels deep make issue more severe

Summary / Abstract: Layoff of employee with subordinates causes subordinates to be lost
Steps to Reproduce: 1. HIRE President1 VP1. 2. HIRE President1 VP2. 3. HIRE VP1 S1. 4. HIRE S1 W1. 5. HIRE S1 W2. 6. LAYOFF President1 VP1. 7. DISPLAY
Expected Result: Supervisor S1 and Workers W1, W2 should remain visible
Actual Result: After layoff, subordinate structure (S1, W1, W2) disappears
Bug Cost: Critical - Layoff doesn't preserve subordinates like Fire does
Notes / Comments: layoff_employee() needs to handle subordinates

Summary / Abstract: Display stops at first vacancy instead of showing deeper levels
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create full hierarchy with VP, S1, S2, W1, W2. 2. FIRE President1 VP1. 3. DISPLAY
Expected Result: Should show VACANCY: Vice President with S1, S2, W1, W2 beneath
Actual Result: Display shows vacancy but not the subordinate supervisors and workers
Bug Cost: Critical - Makes entire subordinate structure invisible
Notes / Comments: _display_loop() doesn't recurse into Vacancy objects

Summary / Abstract: Extremely deep hierarchy with vacancy not displayed properly
Steps to Reproduce: 1. HIRE President1 VP1. 2. HIRE VP1 S1. 3. HIRE S1 W1. 4. QUIT VP1. 5. DISPLAY
Expected Result: Should show: VACANCY: Vice President, then Supervisor: S1, then Worker: W1
Actual Result: Subordinates below vacancy don't display (S1, W1 missing)
Bug Cost: Related to BUG-001 and BUG-013
Notes / Comments: Multiple vacancy levels compound the issue

Summary / Abstract: Multiple vacancies at same level don't all display
Steps to Reproduce: 1. HIRE VP1 with S1, S2, S3. 2. FIRE VP1 S1. 3. FIRE VP1 S2. 4. DISPLAY
Expected Result: Should show 2 VACANCY: Supervisor entries
Actual Result: May only show one vacancy or handle multiple vacancies incorrectly
Bug Cost: Display logic doesn't handle multiple vacancies at same level

Summary / Abstract: All employees at one level removed - vacancies not properly displayed
Steps to Reproduce: 1. HIRE President1 VP1. 2. HIRE President1 VP2. 3. FIRE President1 VP1. 4. FIRE President1 VP2. 5. DISPLAY
Expected Result: Should show vacancies for both removed VPs
Actual Result: Vacancy display may be incomplete or missing
Bug Cost: Edge case for vacancy handling

Summary / Abstract: Names with only spaces accepted as valid
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Enter "   " (3 spaces) as president name
Expected Result: System should reject names containing only whitespace
Actual Result: Program may accept whitespace-only names
Bug Cost: Input sanitization issue
Notes / Comments: _valid_name() should strip and check for empty

Summary / Abstract: Names with newline characters not properly rejected
Steps to Reproduce: 1. HIRE President1 Name\nLine
Expected Result: System should reject names with newline characters
Actual Result: May accept or improperly handle newline in names
Bug Cost: Input validation should check for control characters

Summary / Abstract: Names with underscores accepted
Steps to Reproduce: 1. HIRE President1 User_Name
Expected Result: System should reject special characters including underscore
Actual Result: Accepts underscore in names
Bug Cost: Depends on naming requirements - may be design decision

Summary / Abstract: Names with hyphens/dashes accepted
Steps to Reproduce: 1. HIRE President1 Mary-Jane
Expected Result: System should reject special characters including hyphen
Actual Result: Accepts hyphen in names
Bug Cost: May be acceptable for compound names - verify requirements

Summary / Abstract: Layoff employee under vacancy causes issues
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create hierarchy. 2. FIRE VP1 S1 creating vacancy. 3. LAYOFF VP1 W1 (worker under vacancy). 4. Observe behavior
Expected Result: Worker should be laid off normally or moved to opening
Actual Result: Layoff operation on employee under vacancy may fail or behave unexpectedly
Bug Cost: Operations on employees under vacancies not well-defined

Summary / Abstract: SQL injection attempt in name not validated
Steps to Reproduce: 1. HIRE President1 Robert';DROP TABLE users;--
Expected Result: System should reject malicious input with SQL syntax
Actual Result: May accept SQL injection attempts in name field
Bug Cost: Critical security issue - even if not using SQL database
Notes / Comments: Input validation must sanitize all special characters, quotes, semicolons

Summary / Abstract: Names with escape sequences not properly validated
Steps to Reproduce: 1. HIRE President1 Name\\nWithEscape
Expected Result: System should reject or sanitize escape sequences
Actual Result: May accept backslash escape sequences
Bug Cost: Security and data integrity concern

Summary / Abstract: Hire after quit doesn't preserve subordinate structure
Steps to Reproduce: 1. HIRE President1 VP1. 2. HIRE VP1 S1. 3. HIRE S1 W1. 4. QUIT VP1. 5. HIRE President1 VP2. 6. DISPLAY
Expected Result: New VP2 should inherit the vacancy with S1 and W1 beneath
Actual Result: New hire may not properly connect to existing subordinate structure
Bug Cost: Hiring into vacancy should preserve reports

Summary / Abstract: Maximum nesting with full organization causes display issues
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create full org: President with 2 VPs, each VP with 3 Supervisors, fill workers. 2. QUIT VP1. 3. DISPLAY
Expected Result: Should show VACANCY with all subordinates (S1, S2, S3) and their workers
Actual Result: Subordinates under quit VP disappear from display
Bug Cost: Complex scenario combining multiple issues
Notes / Comments: Related to BUG-001 - display with vacancies

Summary / Abstract: Nested vacancy display completely broken
Steps to Reproduce: 1. HIRE President1 VP1. 2. HIRE VP1 S1. 3. HIRE S1 W1. 4. FIRE President1 VP1. 5. FIRE President1 S1. 6. DISPLAY
Expected Result: Should show: VACANCY: Vice President, VACANCY: Supervisor, Worker: W1
Actual Result: Only shows VP vacancy, nested supervisor vacancy and worker don't appear
Bug Cost: Critical - Nested vacancies completely break display
Notes / Comments: _display_loop() issue with Vacancy recursion

Summary / Abstract: Layoff VP with subordinates causes data loss in display
Steps to Reproduce: 1. HIRE President1 VP1. 2. HIRE President1 VP2. 3. HIRE VP1 Super1. 4. HIRE Super1 W1. 5. LAYOFF President1 VP1. 6. DISPLAY
Expected Result: Super1 and W1 should remain visible even after VP1 laid off
Actual Result: Subordinates disappear from display (Super1, W1 missing)
Bug Cost: Critical - Same display issue as Fire and Quit

Summary / Abstract: Deep hierarchy not visible after mid-level removal
Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create: President->VP1->S1,S2->W1,W2,W3. 2. FIRE President1 VP1. 3. DISPLAY
Expected Result: All 6 items should be visible: VACANCY, S1, S2, W1, W2, W3
Actual Result: Only shows President and VACANCY; all 6 subordinates disappear
Bug Cost: Critical - Complete loss of visibility for entire subtree

Summary / Abstract: Supervisor fired - workers remain but not visible
Steps to Reproduce: 1. HIRE VP1 Super1. 2. HIRE Super1 W1, W2, W3. 3. FIRE VP1 Super1. 4. DISPLAY
Expected Result: Should show: VACANCY: Supervisor with W1, W2, W3 beneath
Actual Result: Vacancy shows but W1
Bug Cost: Critical - Workers exist in system but invisible in display

Summary / Abstract: VP quits - subordinates should remain visible but don't
Steps to Reproduce: 1. HIRE President1 VP1. 2. HIRE VP1 Super1. 3. HIRE Super1 Worker1. 4. QUIT VP1. 5. DISPLAY
Expected Result: Should show: VACANCY: Vice President, Supervisor: Super1, Worker: Worker1
Actual Result: Vacancy shows, but Super1 and Worker1 are missing from display
Bug Cost: Critical - Identical to BUG-001 but triggered by QUIT instead of FIRE
Notes / Comments: Same root cause in _display_loop()
